newsitem.title: USA: NHL ICE HOCKEY-ROY'S SHUTOUT STREAK ENDS BUT COLORADO WINS AGAIN.
newsitem.headline: NHL ICE HOCKEY-ROY'S SHUTOUT STREAK ENDS BUT COLORADO WINS AGAIN.

text.p: Patrick Roy's remarkable post-season shutout streak finally came to an end but he tied the NHL record for career playoff victories as the Colorado Avalanche beat the Chicago Blackhawks 3-1 on Friday.

Mike Keane and Sandis Ozolinsh scored 73 seconds apart in the first period to give the defending Stanley Cup champions a two games to none lead in the best-of-seven first-round Western Conference playoff series.
Roy made 24 saves for his 88th career post-season win, tying him with former New York Islander Billy Smith.

Roy fell about 18 minutes short of the longest shutout streak in playoff history. Roy took a shutout streak of 213 minutes and 11 seconds -- dating back to last year's Stanley Cup Finals -- into Friday's game.

The streak ended at 231 minutes and four seconds when James Black took a pass from Jeff Shantz and flipped a wrist shot into the open side of the Colorado goal at 17:53 of the first period. The longest shutout sequence in playoff history is 248 minutes, 32 seconds by Detroit's Norm Smith in 1936.
"I played with Patrick (Roy) in Montreal and he is one tough goalie in the playoffs," said Chicago defenceman Chris Chelios.
Claude Lemieux, who has won Stanley Cups with three different teams, restored the two-goal Avalanche lead by beating Jeff Hackett at 7:30 of the second period.
"We came out hard and set the tone early and that was the key," said Lemieux.
Hackett made 30 saves for the Blackhawks.
In Detroit, Red Wings fans breathed a sigh of relief when their team tied its series with the Blues at one-game each to avoid going to St Louis down 2-0.
Kris Draper and Larry Murphy scored in a 3:04 span of the third period as Detroit, which was shut out in Game One, posted a 2-1 victory over St Louis.
Draper had a short-handed goal for the Red Wings, who killed all seven St Louis power plays, including a 5-on-3 advantage for 76 seconds late in the third period.
Mike Vernon finished with 22 saves for Detroit.
"We had to get this win. You can feel the pressure lift," said Detroit coach Scotty Bowman. "This will be a long series, maybe seven games."
Marc Bergevin scored for St Louis just 4:24 into the game for a 1-0 lead that the Blues carried into the third period.
St Louis goalie Grant Fuhr blanked the Red Wings for the first 100 minutes of the series, but Detroit finally got to him with Draper's short-handed tally at 4:05 of the third.
"I think there was elation and a lot of relief," Murphy said of Draper's goal. "We said, 'Hey, we can actually score against this guy.'"
The Red Wings took the lead at 7:09 of the third when Fuhr coughed up a rare rebound on a shot by Martin Lapointe and Murphy pounced on the puck and buried it in the St Louis net.
Fuhr finished with 31 saves for St. Louis.
"Grant Fuhr was spectacular," Blues coach Joel Quenneville said. "He shut them out for five periods, but we've got to score some goals ourselves."
In Dallas, Curtis Joseph stopped 25 shots for his third career post-season shutout as the Edmonton Oilers blanked the Stars 4-0 to even their series at one game apiece.
Mike Grier gave Joseph all the support he needed with a first-period powerplay goal, converting a perfect cross-slot pass from Doug Weight with 5:09 left.
Mariusz Czerkawski tallied in the second period and Ryan Smyth and Boris Mironov added third-period goals for Edmonton.
Joseph, whose nickname is Cujo, faced just two shots in the first period but had to make 14 saves in the second and nine in the third.

He was at his best early in the second period when Dallas had a 5-on-3 powerplay. "Cujo came up huge when we were down on that 5-on-3," Oilers coach Ron Low said. "I counted three huges saves that he had on the power play that kept them from getting any momentum."
The Oilers killed off all seven Dallas power plays.
"Now we go home for two games with this as a confidence booster," said Weight, who also assisted on Mironov's powerplay goal. "We can win this series."

In Anaheim, J.J. Daigneault scored twice, including the go-ahead goal with 6:24 remaining, as the Mighty Ducks beat the Phoenix Coyotes 4-2 to take a two games to none lead in their best-of-seven first-round series.

Daigneault put the Ducks ahead to stay when he skated around the back of the Phoenix net and scored on a wraparound while Coyotes' goalie Nikolai Khabibulin and his defencemen were busy watching the dangerous Teemu Selanne in front.
Selanne sealed the victory by scoring into an empty net with seven seconds remaining.
Daigneault's first goal at 7:03 of the second broke a 1-1 tie. Dmitri Mironov had the other goal for the Ducks, who have not lost in their last 16 home games.
Teppo Numminen, who gave Phoenix an early 1-0 lead and Keith Tkachuk, who led the league with 52 goals this season, tied it, 2-2 at 3:55 of the third period for the Coyotes.
